Incident.Summary: Consensual encounter resulting in DUI & less than 10 grams.

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText: Maryland State Police - Easton Barrack (I), Marked Patrol Vehicle I-59 which is equipped with a mobile recording device. Defendant: Ralph Edouard Date of Birth: 11/03/1985 Date of Arrest: 03/06/2023 Time of Arrest: 0247 CT SDX: 119252627 Troopers Training/Experience: Trained in administering Standardized Field Sobriety Tests through the Eastern Shore Criminal Justice Academy, the Maryland State Police and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Trained and certified to operate RADAR and LIDAR through the Centreville Police Department and the Maryland State Police. Certified in Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement (ARIDE) through the Eastern Shore Criminal Justice Academy. Certified Field Training Officer Caroline County Deputy for four years and six months, reaching the rank of Deputy First Class. Maryland State Trooper for 7 months. Phase 1: Vehicle in Motion On Monday, March 6, 2023, at approximately 0217 hours, I, Trooper C. Cooper #7501, was on scene of a single vehicle crash in the area of eastbound Route 50 at Bolingbroke Lane, Trappe, Talbot County, Maryland 21673. While on scene of the crash, I was contacted via radio by Cpl. Moore in reference to a vehicle stopped in traffic with the operator appearing to be asleep. Cpl. Moore requested that I go make contact with the operator to ensure that he was OK. Cpl. Moore described the vehicle to be a red Dodge minivan with the operator being an African American male. I began to approach the vehicle and identified it as a red 2005 Dodge Grand Caravan, red in color, displaying Virginia registration 9763XF. As I began to get closer to the vehicle, I observed the operator resting his head against the drivers side window. Phase 2: Personal Contact I then knocked on the window in order to make contact with the operator of the vehicle. The operator attempted to roll down the window but realized that the vehicle had stopped running because the ignition key had been turned to the idle position where it runs off the battery for a certain amount of time. The operator then turned the vehicle on and rolled down the window to speak with me. As the window rolled down I detected the odor of marijuana emanating from within the vehicle. I requested that the operator provide me with his drivers license. As the operator looked back and forth across the vehicle and began to move items I observed that his movements were slow and lethargic. The operator ultimately provided me with this license and was identified as Ralph Eduoard. I began to ask Ralph where he was coming from and going to. Ralph stated that he was coming from Baltimore and had left there at approximately midnight. I inquired on where Ralph was traveling to and he stated Crisfield, Maryland. As I continued to speak with Ralph I observed his speech to also be slow and lethargic, along with bloodshot eyes. Ralph stated that he was trying to sleep because he had been driving for a long time. I then revisited my previously asked questions on where he was coming from and going to. Ralph stated that he left Crisfield at approximately 1700-1800 hours on Sunday, March 5, 2023 to go to Baltimore. I asked Ralph again where he was coming from and he stated Popeyes. Once TFC. Hansley, arrived on scene, I requested that Ralph exit the vehicle in order for me to conduct a probable cause search of the vehicle. Ralph inquired on why he was being asked to exit the vehicle and I advised him due to the odor of marijauna and the suspicion of possibly operating a vehicle while under the influence. Ralph exited the vehicle and his wife, identified as Gertide Eduoard, did as well. It should be noted that there was also a 7 month old infant within the vehicle who was not properly restrained. The infant was within an infant seat, but was not strapped in and there were several blankets underneath and overtop of the infant. I did not observe the infant carrier to have a base properly strapped into the seat as well. I then conducted a probable cause search of the vehicle. At the completion of the probable cause search, I located 1.5 grams of marijuana within Gertides purse. Gertide was ultimately cited and released from the scene. The evidence was identified as a controlled dangerous substance through my training, knowledge and experience. All evidence was transported back to the barrack where it was packaged and stored according to policy and procedure. After the probable cause search I then advised Ralph that I needed him to perform Standardized Field Sobriety Tests (SFSTs) and he agreed. Phase 3: Pre-Arrest Screening The evaluation was performed on flat level ground which was free of debris. It was approximately 40 degrees and dark. Ralph was wearing black jeans, a t-shirt, zip-up jacket and Hey-Dude style shoes. I asked Ralph the following questions: Medical Conditions - Ralph stated he had none. Injuries - Ralph stated he had none. The first test given was the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus Test. The tip of my finger was used as the tests stimulus and held approximately 12 inches from Ralphs eyes. He was instructed to look straight ahead, keeping his head still while following and focusing on the tip of the stimulus with his eyes until told to stop. His pupils were equal in size and showed equal tracking with no resting nystagmus. Ralph was asked if he understood the test and the instruction to which he stated, Yes. Lack of Smooth Pursuit - Present in both eyes Distinct and Sustained Nystagmus at Maximum Deviation - Present in both eyes Onset of Nystagmus Prior to 45 Degrees - Not observed. Vertical Nystagmus - Not observed. Walk and Turn (6/8 Clues): Prior to Ralph performing the test, I properly explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted. Ralph was instructed to place his right foot directly in front of his left foot and touch heel to toe. He was instructed and demonstrated to place his hands flat at his sides and remain in that position until told to begin. He was advised to take nine (9) steps on a straight-line touching heel to toe on every step. He was instructed to keep his hands flat at his sides, keep his eyes focused on his feet and to count every step aloud. On the ninth step, Ralph was explained and demonstrated to keep his lead foot on the line, take a series of small steps to turn around and completely turn around. Ralph was again explained and demonstrated the second series of nine (9) steps were to be performed identical to the first series. He was instructed that once she began the test that he was not to stop walking until the test was completed, his hands down by his sides, look down at his feet, and count each step out loud. Ralph was asked if he understood the test and the instructions to which he states, Yes. Instructional Stage: Ralph did not remain in the instructional position and began the test prior to being told to do so. Walking Stage (1st Nine): Ralph missed heel to toe, stepped offline, and raised his arms for balance during the first nine steps. Ralph also took the improper amount of steps and stopped after his seventh and eighth step and continued to ask for further instruction on what to do. Ralph ultimately stopped completing the test. Turn: Was not completed. Walking Stage (2nd Nine): Was not completed. One Leg Stand (3 / 4 Clues): Prior to Ralph performing the test, I properly explained and demonstrated how the test should be performed. He was instructed to stand with his heels together and hands down by his sides while the instructions were given. When instructed to start, he was to raise the foot of his choice (right foot), off the ground approximately six (6) inches. While his leg was raised he was to keep his leg straight, watch his raised foot, and to count out loud by thousands (one thousand-one, one thousand-two) and to continue the test until told to stop. He was asked if he understood the test and the instructions to which he stated, Yes. While completing the test Ralph placed his foot down, swayed and raised his arms for balance on multiple occasions within the first 10 seconds. Ralph at one point switched from raising his left foot to raising his right foot without being told to do so. Ralph stopped completing the test and complained about it being too cold outside. I advised Ralph to zip up his jacket and he responded by stating his jacket was not good enough. I provided Ralph with one more opportunity to complete the one leg stand and the same clues as previously stated were observed the second time. Preliminary Breath Test (PBT): .00 Arrest: Based on the following, I had reason to believe Ralph was driving a motor vehicle under the influence: Bloodshot, glassy eyes. Slurred, lethargic speech. Clues during field sobriety. Due to the observations, I concluded that Ralph was driving while impaired by a possible controlled dangerous substance. At approximately 0247 hours, on Monday, March 6, 2023, I placed Ralph under arrest and placed him in the front seat of my patrol vehicle per department policy. While on scene Ralph was provided with a copy of the DR-15 and advised to follow along while the audio version was played. At the completion of the recording Ralph agreed to take the test at approximately 0306 hours. I then transported Ralph to the Maryland State Police - Easton Barrack I. Once at the Barrack, Cpl. Moore conducted the intoximeter test and later advised me that Ralph provided a breath sample which concluded a .00. I then contacted TFC. Cambra who is a certified Drug Recognition Expert (DRE) to see if he conducts an evaluation of Ralph. TFC. Cambra responded to the barrack for the evaluation. Once TFC. Cambra was at the barrack, I advised Ralph of his Miranda rights. Ralph agreed to speak with TFC. Cambra and myself. TFC. Cambra requested that Ralph conduct a test for his evaluation and Ralph agreed. At the completion of the evaluation, TFC. Cambra explained to Ralph that he had concluded Ralph was under the influence of a controlled dangerous substance and requested that he submit to a blood draw. Ralph agreed. (See TFC. Cambras supplemental report for further information.) I then transported Ralph to the University of Maryland Shore Regional Health - Easton. Once at the hospital, contact was made with a nurse on staff in the emergency room, Krista Wooters. Krista completed the blood draw at approximately 0641 hours. All vials containing Ralphs blood were packaged according to policy and procedure and later placed in the mail to be sent to the Chemical Test Unit. Ralph was then released from the hospital with all charging documents and other related documents from the hospital. All events occurred in Talbot County, Maryland.

Suspect: Ralph Edouard Date of Birth: 11/03/1985 Date of Arrest: 03/06/2023 Time of Arrest: 0247 hours Rolling Log Number: 23-004-0021 Training/Certificates: I am trained by the Maryland State Police and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to administer Standardized Field Sobriety Tests (SFSTs) Trained in Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement (ARIDE) Trained and certified as a Drug Recognition Expert (DRE) Attended and successfully completed 2022 DUI College Attended the 2021 DUI Conference Breath Alcohol Test The test was conducted at the Maryland State Police Easton Barrack. Edouard had a breath test result of .00. Interview of Arresting Officer On 3/6/2023, I, TFC Cambra #7191 made contact with Trooper Cooper #7501 at the Maryland State Police Easton Barrack in regards to a suspected impaired driver that was placed under arrest. The driver was identified as Ralph Edouard (DOB: 11/03/1985). Trooper Cooper advised me that he came in contact with Edouard after another unit observed him to be asleep against the window of his vehicle while traffic was stopped for a collision further down the road on East Bound Ocean Gateway, prior to the Malkus Bridge. Trooper Cooper stated that he observed Edouard to be asleep against the window upon his arrival. After gaining Edouards attention, Edouard lowered the window. An odor of marijuana was detected emanating from the vehicle. A probable cause search of the vehicle was conducted which resulted in the recovery of suspected cannabis. Trooper Cooper advised clues during Standardized Field Sobriety Tests were HGN (4/6), WAT (6/8), OLS (3/4). Trooper Cooper advised Edouard of his Miranda Rights at the barrack where he agreed to continue to speak. Preliminary Examination Edouard stated last ate chicken from Popeyes at approximately 1200 am. He stated he last had two bottles of water approximately an hour ago. Edouard estimated the time to be 2 AM at 0507 hours. I asked him when he last slept. He stated the night before (Saturday Night) for approximately 5-6 hours. Edouard denied being sick or injured. He also stated that he was not diabetic or epileptic. Edouard denied taking insulin. He stated he had no physical defects and that he is not under the care of a doctor or dentist. He denied taking any medications or drugs. While speaking with Eduardo, I observed his speech to be slightly slow at times. Edouard stated that he had a young child, and is tired. Edouards first pulse was recorded to be 70 beats per minute at 0504 hours which is within the DRE average range of 60 to 90 beats per minute. Eye Examinations Edouard denied wearing any glasses or contacts. His eyes appeared to be bloodshot. He denied being blind in either eye. He displayed equal tracking and equal pupil size. I observed no resting nystagmus. Edouards eyelids appeared to be normal. Edouard was able to follow the stimulus. I observed Lack of Smooth Pursuit in both eyes as well as Distinct and sustained Nystagmus maximum deviation in both eyes (HGN 4/6). Angle of onset was not observed. I observed no vertical nystagmus. I observed a lack of convergence. I observed his right pupil to move down the corner of his eye, then quickly look forward. Divided attention tests Modified Romberg Balance: Edouard had an approximate 1 circular clockwise sway. I observed him to have eyelid tremors. Edouard stated he reached a 30 second time frame in 23 seconds. Walk and Turn (4/8) Edouard was wearing sandals for the test. Instructional Phase: Cannot keep balance First 9 Steps: Stops walking 9 Misses heel-toe 7 Raises arms 1, 4 Second 9 Steps: Missed heel-toe: 4, 7 Raises arms Turn: After taking his last step on first 9 steps, Edouard stopped and stated turn? before completing the turn. One Leg Stand (3/4) While Edouard balanced on his left foot, he swayed while balancing, and used his arms to balance and counted to approximately to 21 seconds in a 30 second time frame. While balancing on his right foot, Edouard swayed while balancing, used arms to balance, and put his foot down and counted to 28 seconds in a 30 second time frame. Finger to Nose 1) Left: Touched upper lip then finger drifted to tip of nose 2) Right: Touched upper lip then moved up to tip of nose 3) Left: Hovered over nose then touched tip of nose with pad of finger 4) Right: Hovered just above tip of nose then touched tip of nose with pad of finger 5) Right: Touched tip of nose with pad of finger 6) Left: Touched tip of nose with pad of finger Examination of Vital Signs Edouards second pulse was recorded at 64 beats per minute which is within the DRE average range of 60 to 90 beats per minute. Edouards body temperature was 97.2 degrees Fahrenheit which is below the DRE average range of 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit (+/- 1 degree). Edouards blood pressure was 124/90 mmHg, with the systolic being within the DRE average range of 120 140 however on the low end, and the diastolic and being on the top of the DRE average range of 70 90. Dark Room Examinations In room light, Edouards left pupil was 5.5mm which is above the DRE average range of 2.5mm-5mm while his right eye was recorded to be 5mm which is on the top of the DRE average range of 2.5mm to 5mm. In near total darkness, his pupils were 8mm in his left eye and 8.5 mm in his right eye which is on the top end of the DRE average range of 5mm to 8.5mm. In direct light, his pupils were 3.5mm in both eyes which is within the DRE average range of 2mm to 4.5mm. Edouard held his eye lids open to complete the measurement. The measurement was taken after a second 90 second wait. I observed rebound dilation with a normal reaction to light. I observed him to have a deviated septum. His mouth had a purple/green hue under a UV light and a dark mark on the center of his upper lip. Examination of Muscle Tone Edouards muscle tone appeared to be normal Examination of Injection Sites On Edouards right arm, I observed an abundance of scaring on his upper arm. He stated it was from belt from his father at a young age. On his left arm, I observed what appeared to be an old mark on his upper forearm. I also observed additional old scarring. Edouards third pulse was 68 beats per minute which is within the DRE average range of 60 90 beats per minute (taken after statements). Subjects Statements and other Observations Edouard continued to stated that he has not taken anything. He stated maybe food but continued to deny any use of medications or controlled dangerous substance. Opinion I completed a full drug influence evaluation of Edouard. As a certified Drug Recognition Expert (DRE), it is my conclusion and opinion that Edouard was under the influence of Cannabis, Narcotic Analgesic, and a Central Nervous System Depressant and unable to operate a vehicle safely based on: .00 BrAC inconsistent with psychophysical impairment Depressed body temperature Presence of HGN and Lack of convergence Rebound dilation present Green hue to tongue under UV light Altered time perception Impaired memory during WAT test Drowsiness Unsteady walk Eyelid Tremors margin-bottom:11px">Slow speech at times Toxicology Exam Edouard agreed to a blood test. He was transported to the University of Maryland Shore Regional Health Easton where a sample of his blood was taken. Miscellaneous TFC Cambra #7191 Maryland State Police Easton Barrack I Drug Recognition Expert #36473
On 8/3/2023, I, TFC Cambra #7191 received the blood test results for Edouard. The lab test results none detected at the time of the testing.

On Monday, August 22, 2023, I was contacted by Sgt. C. Del Vecchio in reference to this case. Sgt. C. Del Vecchio provided me with the blood kit results which had no controlled dangerous substances detected. Contact was made with the Talbot County States Attorney Office who advised that due to there being no substances detected they would nolle prosequi the charges. I request this case be closed due to the lack of prosecution from the SAO.
